newsitem.title: CROATIA: Croatian money market rates rise amid low liquidit.
newsitem.headline: Croatian money market rates rise amid low liquidit.

text.p: Croatian money market rates were pushed higher amid low liquidity on Monday, dealers said.
"The market has seen a very high demand for kuna which has not been matched by the money on offer," one dealer said.
She explained that the current shortage came after banks settled monthly pension payments at the end of last week.
Fresh loans totalled 33.9 million kuna and were mostly call money borrowings at 11 percent, up 50 basis points from last week.
"Another 25 million kuna is still being sought," the dealer said.
Term loans, accounting for some 11 million kuna fresh trade, were struck at between 10 percent for short-term insurer money and 17 percent for one-month interbank funds.

The weekend overnight trade totalled 51.6 million kuna, sought by seven banks to square their position and one bank to maintain its mandatory reserve. -- Sandra Kalogjera, Zagreb Newsroom, 385-1-4557075
